bug.short_desc: Executing ConcordanceH2DatabaseUpdater provides problems for custom/other concordance clients

long_desc.thetext:

Now I have a custom concordance client, which is added to the list of listeners by using the ModelChangeListener extension point. Due to this my custom client is called after the database has been updated (as the ConcordanceH2DatabaseUpdater is added before my custom client). So it finding model elements that have cross references to the renamed model is not possible anymore as this is a database operation and the database is already updated to reflect the new situation.
An solution would be to (somehow) execute ConcordanceH2DatabaseUpdater after all other listeners are executed/informed about the change. The same goes for any other default clients that modifies the database to keep it up to date with the changed situation (if there are any others).

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Can produces wrong type of newlines in generated files when templates are written and executed on different OSs

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, if an EGL template contains newline characters from one operating system (say Windows) and that template is executed on another operating system (say UNIX) then any generated text will contain the Windows newline characters.
This problematic for preventing generated files from being overwritten if their contents would not be changed by the overwrite operation. Java seems to normalise newline characters to the current OS when loading files from disk. This means that we cannot accurately detect whether text generated from a later invocation of the template is different from the file currently on disk as, for the example above, the former would contain Windows newline characters and the latter UNIX newline characters.

I've committed a fix for this in r2434. We now normalise all newline characters emitted by a template by rewriting newline characters in static sections in the Preprocessor.
In the future, we might want to consider adding Windows and UNIX formatters. These would be postprocessors that rewrite newline characters so that files generated via EGL running on UNIX could be used on Windows, and vice-versa.
Fixed in the latest interim version.

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Provide mechanism for turning on and off preservation of unchanged files

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, EGL will always attempt to prevent writes to disk when the generated text is the same as the contents of the existing file. This can be unhelpful when we want to benchmark the performance of EGL, particularly whilst we explore approaches to incremental transformation.
We need a mechanism for turning on or off this behaviour.

Patch in r2435. I've added support for this (and any future related settings) via a new IncrementalitySettings class. These settings can be changed on a template factory (in which case they are bubbled down to all templates created by that factory) or on individual templates:
templateFactory.getDefaultIncrementalitySettings().setOverwriteUnchangedFiles(false);
template.getIncrementalitySettings().setOverwriteUnchangedFiles(true)
By default isOverwriteUnchangedFiles will return false.

bug.short_desc: [EOL] Support for setting content of an xml/xsd mixed complex type

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 236894 Example solution for modifying the mixed attribute
An xml element specified in the xsd has having a mixed complex type ends up with a pseudo-addribute "mixed". This is an EFeatureMap, in which the values represent the sequence of children, indeed a mixed collection of further XML elements and character data.
Accessing the character data is possible using the functionality of the mixed attribute (though that is not as straightforward as one would like) but modifying it is a pain, because the FeatureMap needs keys of the right type, and these are not easy to construct. See the attached zip for an example of how I solved this in the end (based on the available xsdxml example).
It would be very helpful if EOL provided support for this functionality. There are two levels on which this could be done:
1. Low-level support: an auxiliary operation "setText" on the mixed attribute, which inserts a string into the map. (You could have an indexed version to allow insertion at arbitrary places, and an unindexed version for appending.)
2. High-level support: an auxiliary operation "setContent" on the xml element itself, which appends a string to its mixed attribute. This would avoid the mixed attribute altogether.
--Arend

Thanks for reporting this. I've extended the example under [1] to demonstrate adding text to mixed elements without the need for an auxiliary file, but I agree that a more elegant solution would be desirable.

I do agree that we may need to revise the code to produce more accurate stack traces, though.

I wouldn't be too worried about performance: all the new IExecutionListener would do would be to keep a stack of ASTs and push/pop ASTs there in its aboutToExecute/finishedExecuting methods. A potential advantage over the current solution is that we won't need to change the API of exceptions (when I updated, I had to fix a couple of drivers that are not in the main SVN as the signature of EolIllegalPropertyAssignmentException now includes an extra parameter). I suspect that we'd need to make more changes in a couple of places to support more fine-grained traces - while if we go with the IExecutionListener we won't need to modify anything other than install a new listener to the executor factory.

That makes sense. How would we print the stack trace, though? Someone would have to get a reference to the concrete IExecutionListener, grab the current stack trace and place it into the exception message. I'm not sure who would be responsible for that: E*L code can be called from many different places.

Instead of changing client code all over the place, could we use a mix of our two approaches?
We could use an IExecutionListener to track the stack trace, and then place a catch block on E*LModule#execute which would add a detailed stack trace to the thrown exception (wrapping the original exception if necessary) and rethrow it.

That could potentially work but we'll need to decide how the Epsilon stack trace should be combined with the Java stack trace (when Epsilon is used in an embedded mode, the Java stack trace can be useful). For now, I'd suggest reverting the code in the SVN to version 2345, applying 2347 on top of it and taking it from there. In the first instance, I'll prototype the IExecutionListener-based solution and when we're happy with it we can investigate how we want client code to make use of this information. Does this sound sensible?
Sure! Shall I do the revert, then?
That'd be great!
Done! :-)

Thanks! I've committed a solution that appears to be working well so far. To overcome the context-less EolRuntimeException issue, I've made ASTs aware of the IModule they are a part of. As such a runtime exception can get hold of the module of its AST, its context and eventually the stack trace manager.
I've also modified the format of the reported error locations in the console so that we can navigate to the exact coordinates of the offending ASTs. Could you please have a go at it and let me know what you think?

bug.short_desc: EvlValidator should support configurable error handling

long_desc.thetext:
Copied from http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/523935/
--- Hello,
Sometimes I am getting a ridiculous amount of validation exceptions (shown in the same amount of dialogs, making my system quite unresponsive). So I thought it is time to prevent this (e.g. by ignoring validation problems after 10 are found). With the current EvlValidator class this is not really possible.
The EvlValidator.validate(Resource, Map<Object, Object>) catches exception and show them in a log + dialog. I have some thoughts about this:
When an exception is caught, the validation should be canceled... Now it continues, which is not likely the perform the validation correctly. The method does not provide means to let the callee know whether an exception occurred... E.g. via a return value or a rethrown exception
My opinion is to cancel the validation when an exception occurs (point 1) and throw a new exception telling what went wrong (point 2), instead of directly logging them. The newly thrown exception can be caught in the validate(EClass, EObject, DiagnosticChain, Map<Object, Object>) method and added to the log, to keep the default behavior.
But now a custom validator is able to handle them as desired. E.g. keeping a counter and stop showing the exceptions after a certain threshold is reached.
Any additional thoughts about this subject?
Again, I am willing to provide a patch when a consensus is achieved.
Have a good weekend! Cheers, Maarten ---
Fixed in the SVN (r2395)
Fixed in the latest interim version.

long_desc.thetext:
This bug report stems from the discussion in this forum thread:
http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/m/1109345/#msg_1109345
When SVG support was first added to Eugenia (in Indigo, IIRC) it required the experimental GMF tooling SDK. It was the same during Juno as well. Among other things, when using SVG-based figures Eugenia would add dependencies to two plugins: org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.lite and org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.lite.svg.
Kepler has improved the situation considerably: runtime.lite.svg is now part of the standard GMF distribution and does not require runtime.lite anymore. However, Eugenia is still adding the dependency on runtime.lite, which prevents the generated plugin from working correctly.

bug.short_desc: Support custom EvlValidator implementations

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 235414 Adds custom EvlValidator support
As discussed in http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/521880/ the custom EvlValidator allows one to modify the validation behavior of the EVL constraints. (In my case to cache results to increase to the speed of live validation)
The patch adds a validation attribute to the constraintsBinding which is used to create the custom EvlValidator object (if the attribute is used). The default behaviour does not change.
Unfortunately, createExecutableExtension() is not possible to call constructors with parameters. Therefore, an initialise() method is added to EvlValidator to provide the 'constructor parameters' after the class has been instantiated.

EvlValidator has some private methods:
* addMarkers(String, EObject, DiagnosticChain) * void validate(Resource, Map<Object, Object>)
it would be great if these change be changed to protected, so they are usable from the custom EvlValidator implementations!

The patch looks simple enough, but could you preserve the original EvlValidator constructor in addition to the new no-arg constructor? Someone could be using it, and we wouldn't want to break their code. You could have it invoke the initialize method, in order to avoid duplicating code.

Created attachment 235415 Adds custom EvlValidator support v2
Good idea.
I also changed the visibility of both methods to protected (assuming this would not be a problem)
Sure, feel free to change those methods to protected access :-).
I already did... :-D

I guess you're preventing multiple initialization in order to better simulate the semantics of the old four-arg constructor, right?
I think that's a good idea, but perhaps you should add an else branch to the initialize(...) method that logs a warning to the Error Log view if someone tries to initialize an already initialized EvlValidator. Otherwise, they might be left scratching their heads when it doesn't pick up their values. (I've been bitten by silent errors before, and it's not nice :-D)
You could use something like:
Activator.getDefault().getLog().log(...)

Created attachment 235417 Adds custom EvlValidator support v3
Yes, it prevents calling initialise() twice, as it will probably break things badly (assuming it uses different values).
Updated the patch to generate a warning when initialise() is called twice (or after the original constructor is used).
To make it even nicer, one should/could check if initialise() is called before making use of the class. Although, I guess this results in a lot of overhead, as this is checked every time validate() is called and therefore not worth it.
Personally, I would not do this, do you agree?

No, I think it's good enough to assume that users will read the prominently displayed note in the javadoc for the default constructor... or else :-).
I think the patch is ready for integration now.
Patch integrated in SVN r2384.
